formName: Tell HMRC about a company failing to stop people evading tax

sections.title: Which of these best describes the business you are reporting?

fields.helpText: If you are unsure please choose company

sections.title: Are you authorised by the company to make this report?

fields.label: Are you authorised by the company to make this report?
optionHelpText: You can only use this form to self-report on behalf of a company. To report another company, or an individual taxpayer, exit this service and contact the HMRC fraud hotline.

sections.title: Is some or all of the evaded tax owed in the UK?

fields.label: Is some or all of the evaded tax owed in the UK?
optionHelpText: You can only use this form to self-report a failure to prevent the facilitation of UK tax evasion. Failure to prevent the facilitation of foreign tax evasion should be reported to the Serious Fraud Office. You will need to sign out of this service.

fields.helpText: This is 10 numbers, for example 1234567890. It will be on tax returns and other letters about Corporation Tax. It may be called ‘reference’, ‘UTR’ or ‘official use’. [OPTIONAL]

sections.title: Explain how the criminal facilitation of tax evasion took place

fields.infoText:
Summarise how the tax evasion was facilitated.  

Include details about:

* who within the organisation facilitated the evasion
* the capacity in which they were acting
* who they helped to evade tax 
* what tax was evaded
* how it was discovered

fields.label: When is the facilitation of tax evasion a criminal act?
fields.infoText: For the facilitation of tax evasion to be a criminal act, a person must have deliberately and dishonestly helped another person to evade tax. This doesn’t include the accidental, ignorant or negligent facilitation of tax evasion.

fields.helpText: Enter a maximum of 5000 characters

fields.helpText: Select one or more options

sections.title: Report reference code
sections.description: Create and enter a unique reference code for this report and keep a note of it. HMRC may ask for this, along with your Government Gateway ID and report submission date (both shown below) if we need to contact you about this report.

fields.label: Unique submission reference code
fields.helpText: Create and enter a unique code for this report that is at least 5 characters long, using letters and numbers. For example, JoeSmith1977

sections.title: Create a unique report name

fields.label: repname
fields.infoText:
Enter a name for this report and keep a note of it.
HMRC may use this during further correspondence with you.
If you or the company have previously made a report to HMRC, make sure that you enter a name that has not been used previously.

fields.label: Report name
fields.helpText: Use at least 5 characters, including letters and numbers

sections.title: How HMRC will use your information

fields.infoText:
* the personal data collected from this report will be processed in accordance with data protection law, including the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the Data Protection Act 2018.
* HMRC will collect, use and share information submitted in this report in accordance with our Privacy Notice [Link to privacy notice]

* if the information submitted leads to an investigation, HMRC may share your contact details with other relevant third parties, where necessary

* HMRC may use evidence from this report in a prosecution or other court proceedings, where permitted by law
 
[TICK BOX] I confirm that I understand and agree

choices: I understand and agree that I may commit a criminal offence if I give false information or include information that I don’t honestly believe to be true in this report.

fields.infoText: By submitting this report I declare that the information I have provided is true and complete

[Previous text]     HMRC may use information in your report to decide whether to start a criminal investigation. We may also use evidence from your report in a prosecution or other court proceedings. Where the law permits, we may share the information you have given with other agencies.

HMRC will not contact you again unless we require further information. If an investigation is launched it is likely we will contact you to discuss further details on the case. This can include requesting details of the company or partnership’s prevention procedures.
